articles.headline: Delta Malfunction on Land Keeps a Fleet of Planes From the Sky
articles.snippet: A cascade of delayed and canceled flights on Monday was the latest example of how a failure in an airline’s system can have catastrophic effects.
articles.abstract: A cascade of delayed and canceled flights on Monday was the latest example of how a failure in an airline’s system can have catastrophic effects.
articles.lead_paragraph: Delta Air Lines is working to reset its operations on Tuesday morning, after a power failure grounded flights and led to cancellations and delays a day earlier. As of 12:30 p.m. Eastern time, Delta had canceled more than 500 flights scheduled for Tuesday.

articles.headline: States Vie to Shield the Wealth of the 1 Percent
articles.snippet: Nevada, Delaware and other states compete to offer ways for the rich to fend off creditors, divorcing spouses and even tax collectors.
articles.abstract: Nevada, Delaware and other states compete to offer ways for the rich to fend off creditors, divorcing spouses and even tax collectors.
articles.lead_paragraph: LAS VEGAS — Steven J. Oshins, a Nevada lawyer who specializes in estate planning, has never met the wealthy software entrepreneur Dan Kloiber, but he is nonetheless intensely interested in Mr. Kloiber’s contentious divorce.

articles.headline: Think Tank Scholar or Corporate Consultant? It Depends on the Day
articles.snippet: Acting as independent arbiters to shape government policy, many researchers also have corporate roles that are sometimes undisclosed.
articles.abstract: Acting as independent arbiters to shape government policy, many researchers also have corporate roles that are sometimes undisclosed.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Over the many months that officials in Washington debated sweeping new regulations for internet providers, Jeffrey A. Eisenach, a scholar at the conservative American Enterprise Institute, was hard to miss.
articles.byline: By Eric Lipton, Nicholas Confessore and Brooke Williams

articles.headline: 50 G.O.P. Officials Warn Donald Trump Would Put Nation’s Security ‘at Risk’
articles.snippet: The officials, many of them from the George W. Bush administration, signed a letter declaring that Mr. Trump “would be the most reckless president in American history.”
articles.abstract: The officials, many of them from the George W. Bush administration, signed a letter declaring that Mr. Trump “would be the most reckless president in American history.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Fifty of the nation’s most senior Republican national security officials, many of them former top aides or cabinet members for President George W. Bush, have signed a letter declaring that Donald J. Trump “lacks the character, values and experience” to be president and “would put at risk our country’s national security and well-being.”
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: Donald Trump’s Economic Team Is Far From Typical
articles.snippet: The group he has assembled, mostly businessmen, is atypical in their relative lack of economic credentials.
articles.abstract: The group he has assembled, mostly businessmen, is atypical in their relative lack of economic credentials.
articles.lead_paragraph: Donald Trump, laying out his economic plan on Monday in Detroit, said that the nation must “stop relying on the tired voices of the past.” In what would seem to be yet another jab at Hillary Clinton, he added, “We can’t fix a rigged system by relying on the people who rigged it in the first place.”

articles.headline: Finding Good Pain Treatment Is Hard. If You’re Not White, It’s Even Harder.
articles.snippet: Researchers cite several reasons for the disparity, including evidence of racial bias and stereotyping. The lower level of treatment tends to lead to more disability.
articles.abstract: Researchers cite several reasons for the disparity, including evidence of racial bias and stereotyping. The lower level of treatment tends to lead to more disability.
articles.lead_paragraph: TUSCALOOSA, Ala. — Roslyn Lewis was at work at a dollar store here, pushing a heavy cart of dog food, when something popped in her back: an explosion of pain. At the emergency room the next day, doctors gave her Motrin and sent her home.

articles.headline: Mexico’s Richest Man Confronts a New Foe: The State That Helped Make Him Rich
articles.snippet: Carlos Slim built a business empire that has made him one of the world’s richest men. But Mexico’s leaders have been chipping away at his domain with regulations.
articles.abstract: Carlos Slim built a business empire that has made him one of the world’s richest men. But Mexico’s leaders have been chipping away at his domain with regulations.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — All is not well in the kingdom of Carlos Slim.
articles.byline: By Azam Ahmed, Randal C. Archibold and Elisabeth Malkin

articles.headline: Facebook Blocks Ad Blockers, but It Strives to Make Ads More Relevant
articles.snippet: The programs that prevent websites from displaying ads will be rendered useless for those accessing the social network’s desktop site, but not on mobile browsers.
articles.abstract: The programs that prevent websites from displaying ads will be rendered useless for those accessing the social network’s desktop site, but not on mobile browsers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Digital ads pop up online so frequently and ubiquitously that many people are using software to block them.

articles.headline: M.I.T., N.Y.U. and Yale Are Sued Over Retirement Plan Fees
articles.snippet: Employees contend that each university failed to monitor, and replace, expensive, poor-performing investment options in their retirement plans.
articles.abstract: Employees contend that each university failed to monitor, and replace, expensive, poor-performing investment options in their retirement plans.
articles.lead_paragraph: Three prominent universities were sued on Tuesday, accused of allowing their employees to be charged excessive fees on their retirement savings.
